logging

Class Log

  • java.lang.Object
    • logging.Log

  • public abstract class Log
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides an interface for writing to log files, and changing the file where the logs are kept. To use it, make sure that at the beginning of your program you call Log.start() and at the end you call Log.close(). Also, this class is probably the best way to write to the console, because it logs that as well.
    Author:
    Thomas Woltjer

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public static void start()
        Start logging output

      • close

        public static void close()
        Close the log, and actually write whatever is left in the buffer to the file.

      • write

        public static void write(java.lang.String s,
                         int level)
        Write a line of text to the log file, and possibly the console. This should be used instead of System.out.
        Parameters:
        s - The text to write to the log file
        level - -1 is error, 0 is standard, 1 is debug, 2 is console These are all declared as public constants for this class

      • changeLogFile

        public static void changeLogFile(java.lang.String newLocation)
        Change log file location. This is a save way of doing it, because it closes the PrintWriter for the old logfile, and makes a new one for the new log file.
        Parameters:
        newLocation -

      • isInstantiated

        public static boolean isInstantiated()
        Tell the world if the log has been started
        Returns:
        if this is instantiated
